awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Creating an upper division additive manufacturing course and laboratory for enhancing undergraduate research and innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
American economic and social theorists have predicted that Additive Manufacturing (AM) heralds the beginning of the Third Industrial Revolution, succeeding the production line assembly that has dominated manufacturing since the late 19th century. AM, also known as 3D printing, refers to a process used to create a three-dimensional artifact by printing successive layers of material under computer control. The significant drop in price of 3D printers over the last decade has made them relatively common in undergraduate engineering labs, thereby opening up the opportunity to provide students with extended first-hand experience of AM. The goal of the project is to help K-12 students and engineering undergraduates learn about AM so that they are better prepared for the renaissance in U.S. manufacturing.  Student learning will be supported by the labs, projects, course materials, and a textbook on AM that will be developed during this project. The institutions involved are Texas Tech University (TTU), a university with high research activity (RU/H), California State University, Northridge, a non-PhD-granting institution that is both an HSI (Hispanic Serving Institution) and an AANAPISI (Asian American Native American Pacific Islander Serving Institution), and Kansas State University (KSU), both an EPSCoR and an RU/H institution. 

Through creation of the AM course, the following goals will be met: (1) the development of intellectually rigorous course materials (e.g., textbook, lab manual, lecture notes) that will be publicly accessible via hard copy and a virtual classroom website; (2) the conduct of important educational research on the impact of the new AM curricula on changes in student attitudes and self-efficacy in STEM, the results of which will be published in engineering and education journals; (3) the development of simplified 3D printing projects for K-12 students and Maker Space users. Outreach by engineering undergraduates to K-12 students through one-on-one mentoring relationships will help to build the K-12 STEM pipeline by creating excitement and interest in engineering as a career.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative project, three universities, Kansas State University (KSU), Texas Tech University (TTU), and California State University, Northridge (CSUN), joined forces to achieve two main objectives. First, they established a course and lab focused on additive manufacturing. Second, the project conducted and evaluate educational research to understand the impact of this course on both undergraduate engineering students and K-12 students. Since its commencement in September 2017, the primary investigator (PI) at KSU successfully executed the major pedagogical and research tasks outlined in the project. This includes the creation of a new upper-division undergraduate class and lab named "Additive Manufacturing". This course was approved as a permanent elective course (IMSE 664) in 2019, and has been offered at least once a year by multiple faculties at the PI's home department in the last 5 years. The course has witnessed continuous improvement with the development and refinement of comprehensive course materials such as textbooks, lab manuals, lecture notes, and quizzes. These resources were made publicly accessible. The enrolled students have demonstrated enhanced problem-solving abilities and engineering design skills with strong fundamental knowledge gain and strengthened efficacy.

COVID-19 pandemic hit in the third year of the project. An online classroom with live and recorded lectures and virtual and satellite labs was established thanks to the seamless connection between the physical and digital worlds enabled by additive manufacturing. With the support of this award, 3D printers were checked out for use in students' personal space when in-person learning was interrupted. Student learning outcome assessment showed that their hands-on skill and knowledge gain were not discounted, which provided valuable insights on hands-on learning for remote education. The research findings on the effects of the course on participating undergraduates and K-12 students have been positive, with annual assessments measuring objective subject knowledge gain and subjective self-assessments. Notably, knowledge gain was prominent among female students and students of color, aligning with the project's goal of targeting underserved/underrepresented student populations in engineering.

This project at KSU also encompassed many outreach activities in partnership with the Multicultural Engineering Program and the KSU's chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers, including additive manufacturing workshops for local middle school students during the "Engineering a Dream" annual engineering and science day camp and Multicultural Academic Program Success (MAPS) summer bridge program. The project facilitated the dissemination of results through attendance at ASEE annual conferences, poster presentations, virtual presentations, and published conference papers by the PIs from the three universities.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Meng Zhang
